page.title: 03ARTHUR MEE:LOCAL PERSONALITY
page.content: Arthur Mee was born in Stapleford in 1875, and grew up to be a famous writer of some 80 books for children and adults. He is particularly remembered for his 'Children's Encyclopaedia'. He was a very energetic man, and was editor of The Nottingham Evening News (now defunct) at the age of 20. At 21 he went to London, and shortly afterwards was writing two daily columns and editing a weekly paper at the same time. His output at this time was estimated at 1 million words a year. He died in 1943. His name is carried today by the Arthur Mee Centre in Stapleford, which is used for Adult Education. It is in the building which Arthur Mee himself attended when a boy.
